abstract.p: List of contributors to special section How Race is Lived in America

block.p: Dalton Conley is an associate professor of sociology at New York University and the director of its Center for Advanced Social Science Research. ''Learning Whiteness'' is excerpted from ''Honky,'' to be published in October by the University of California Press.
Debra Dickerson is a senior fellow at the New America Foundation. Her memoir, ''An American Story,'' will be published in September by Pantheon.
Margo Jefferson is a cultural critic for The Times.

Scott L. Malcomson is a journalist who lives in New York. ''My Chinese Phase'' is adapted from ''One Drop of Blood: The American Misadventure of Race,'' to be published in October by Farrar, Straus & Giroux.
Michael O'Neill is a New York-based photographer and a frequent contributor to the magazine. His last picture for the magazine was the cover of a special issue on work (May).
Jeff Riedel is a New York-based photographer. His most recent photographs for the magazine were of Calpernia Addams, a transgendered woman (May).

Paisley Rekdal teaches poetry at the University of Wyoming. ''The Myth of My Family's Laundromat'' is adapted from ''The Night My Mother Met Bruce Lee: Observations on Not Fitting In,'' to be published in October by Pantheon.
Taryn Simon is a New York-based photographer. She has recently covered suburban teenagers, poverty and Chechnya for the magazine.
Don Terry is a national correspondent for The Times.
Archie Tse is a graphics editor for The Times.

Sources for ''Consumed by Race,'' Page 38. Demographics and housing data: Analysis of 1997 American Housing Survey data by Susan Weber and Andrew Beveridge, Queens College sociology department. Product and brand data: Midyear 1999 Consumer Knowledge Suite, Information Resources. Television programs: October 1999 to May 2000, Nielsen Media Research. Magazines: Spring 2000 Survey, Mediamark Research. Religion: 1998 General Social Survey, National Opinion Research Center, University of Chicago. Newspaper readership, magazine subscriptions, television viewing, cordless phones, checking account: 1999 African-American Monitor, Don Coleman Advertising: Yankelovich Partners. Reading to children: 1999 study, National Center for Education Statistics. Telephones: 1998 Current Population Survey, National Telecommunications and Information Administration. Miscellaneous: 1998 Doublebase, Mediamark Research.
